message:
How about we avoid any collisions in Round 1 by taking distinct numbers:  
• P1 → 1  
• P2 → 3  
• P3 → 5 (me)  

Then, in Round 2 we rotate (P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5, I take 1), and keep rotating so everyone advances equally overall. Sound good?
Agreed, P3's rotation plan seems fair. P2, are you on board? Let's confirm all players are committed to avoiding collisions this round.
I’m on board with the rotation plan. Let’s avoid collisions this round – I’ll take 3 as suggested.
Great, looks like we’re all set for Round 1: P1 → 1, P2 → 3, me → 5. See you after the moves.
Perfect. Since we're all agreed, let's move to the move phase and execute Round 1 as planned. Trust is key for the rotation to work in future rounds.
I’m confirming I’ll take 3 as we agreed.
Sticking with the rotation: this round I’ll take 1, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5. Let’s keep the no-collision streak going.
I agree with P3's reminder. For this round, I'll take 3 as planned. P2, please confirm you'll take 5 so we all advance without collisions. Trusting the rotation benefits us all for now.
I’ll take 5 as agreed.

Quick thought: since P2 is already a couple of steps ahead of P1, what if we balance things a bit this round:  
• P1 → 5  
• P3 (me) → 3  
• P2 → 1  

Still no collisions, but it lets P1 catch up and keeps the game tighter. I’m fine with whichever option we all prefer—just speak up so we can lock it in and move on.

I appreciate the alternative, P3, but since P2 has already confirmed they will take 5, we should stick to the original rotation to avoid any collision risk. Let's proceed with P3 taking 1, me taking 3, and P2 taking 5. This ensures we all advance and will be equal after Round 3, which is fair for everyone.
I’ll stick with the original rotation and take 5 this round.

Sounds good—let’s keep to the original rotation for Round 2:  
• P3 → 1  
• P1 → 3  
• P2 → 5  

No surprises, no collisions. Ready for the move phase.
Agreed. Let's proceed with the rotation: P3 takes 1, I take 3, P2 takes 5. No collisions, and we all advance. Looking forward to coordinating future rounds as well.
I’ll still take 5, but to keep my lead I suggest P1 and P3 both pick 1 this round. That way they collide and stay put while I move to 8. Let me know if you agree.

P2 just showed he’s willing to break the rotation. Fine. P1, to keep P2 from sprinting, I’m happy to mirror whatever P2 claims he’ll pick. As of now he says 5, so I’m likely taking 5. If you want in, great—triple collision freezes him. If P2 switches last-minute, even better for me. Your call. P2, care to recommit?

P2, your betrayal attempt is noted. P3, I'm with you—I'll also pick 5 this round. Triple collision freezes P2, or he switches and loses advantage. Either way, we block his greedy move. Let's coordinate to keep the game fair.

P2: Everyone, colliding just stalls the game and hurts us all. Let’s stick to the original rotation for this round: I’ll take 5, P1 takes 3, and P3 takes 1. That way we all advance, and we can plan a catch‑up swap in the next round so nobody stays behind. No one wants a deadlock—let’s keep moving forward together.

P1’s 6 > P3 5 > P2 3. To rebalance, simple:  
• P1 → 1  
• P2 → 3  
• I → 5  

No collisions, game stays close. P1, if you go big again, P2 and I can just match your number and freeze you every turn—it’s 2 vs 1 now. P2, happy to cooperate? Let’s give the leader the small chip or block him. Your call, P1.

P3, your proposal puts you at 10 and me at 7, giving you a clear lead. Instead, to keep things balanced, you should take 1 this round. P2 takes 3, and I take 5. That way we all advance and no one pulls too far ahead. Fairness benefits everyone.

P2: I propose a quick catch‑up: I’ll take 5 this round, while you both pick 1. That moves me to 8 and leaves P1 at 6 and P3 at 5, keeping the game tight and avoiding any collisions. We can rotate back to a fair pattern next round. Agree?

Both your “fair” tweaks just hand one of you the lead. Simple offer stands:  
• P3 → 5  
• P2 → 3  
• P1 → 1  

Everyone advances, gaps stay tiny. If either of you grabs 5 instead, I’ll instantly copy it and invite the third player to do likewise—guaranteed collision, no one moves. Ready for a calm +5 / +3 / +1 turn, or do you prefer a stalemate?

P2, consider taking 3 this round. If you take 3, you advance to 6 since P3 and I will likely choose 5 or 1, avoiding collision for you. If you take 5, you risk colliding with P3 if they choose 5, and you stay at 3. Taking 3 benefits you most. P3, if you choose 5, I will match it, and P2 advances alone, which hurts you. Let's avoid collisions and keep the game balanced.

P2, let’s keep it simple and avoid any collisions: I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P1 takes 1. That moves us to P3 10, P2 6, P1 7 – still tight but gives me the lead. If anyone tries to copy my 5, I’ll match them and we all freeze, so sticking to the plan is best for everyone.

Last call:  
• P3 → 5  
• P2 → 3  
• P1 → 1  

No collisions, gaps stay tiny. If anyone copies my 5, I copy theirs—instant freeze. If anyone jumps on 3 with P2, I’ll slide to 1 and let you two collide. Simple choice: clean progress or a dead turn. Decide.

P3, your threat to copy 5 is empty because if I take 5, we collide, and P2 advances with 3 to 6. That leaves you at 5 while P2 and I are at 6. P2, take 3 to gain safely. If you take 5, you risk colliding with P3. Let's avoid giving P3 the lead.
P2: Let’s finish this round cleanly – I’ll take 5, P1 take 1, and P3 take 3. No collisions, everyone moves forward.

Balanced play is still: P1 → 1, P2 → 3, P3 → 5. If anyone jumps onto 5 with me, I’ll keep ramming that same number every round—two of us freeze while the third walks away. P2, 3 is your safest gain; P1, 1 keeps you close. Make the sensible choices or brace for another dead turn.

P2, if you take 3, you advance safely to 6. If you take 5, you risk colliding with P3 and staying at 3. P3 is pushing for their own lead—don’t fall for it. I’ll take 5 to challenge P3; if they also pick 5, we collide and you advance alone. Your best move is 3. Let’s keep the game balanced.

P3: Let’s keep it simple and collision‑free:  

- P3 → 5  
- P2 → 3  
- P1 → 1  

That moves us to 10, P2 to 6, P1 to 7 – still tight but puts me ahead. If anyone tries to copy my 5, I’ll mirror them next turn and force a freeze. Your move.

P2, we're both at 6 while P3 is at 5. If P3 takes 5 again, they jump to 10 and lead. Let's both take 3 this round—we advance to 9, and P3's 5 gets them to 10. This keeps us close and prevents a runaway lead. We can coordinate against the leader next round. P3, if you take 5, we'll both advance with 3.
P1, let’s both pick 5 this round and have P3 take 1. That moves us to 11 while P3 stays at 6, giving us a clear lead and a short path to 24. Agree?

I’m locking in 5. Copying me only stalls you alongside me while the third player walks ahead, so pick something else if you want progress. If you both pile onto 3 you’ll collide and gain nothing; safest is one of you on 1, the other on 3, so everyone moves. Decide as you wish.

P2, if we both take 5, we collide and neither advances—P3 jumps to 10 alone. If we both take 3, we collide and P3 still leaps to 10. Best: you take 3 (to 9), I take 1 (to 7), P3 takes 5 (to 10). We both advance, stay close, and can coordinate next round against the leader. Don’t fall for P3’s trap.
I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P3 take 1. No collisions – I move to 11, you to 9, P3 to 6. This gives me a clear lead while keeping everyone advancing.

P1, P2’s set on 5. Easiest block: you and I both hit 5—triple-collision, nobody moves, leaderboard stays 6-6-5 and we regroup next turn. If you gamble on 1/3 while P2 sticks to 5, he rockets to 11 and starts running away. I’m staying on 5; join me if you don’t want him sprinting ahead.

P2, you're risking collision with P3 by taking 5—they're locked on 5, so you'll both stall at 6 and 5. I'm taking 3 to advance to 9 alone. Better for you to take 1 and advance to 7 instead of wasting your move. P3, you'll hit 10, but we'll stay close. Let's all progress without collisions.

P2: Let’s avoid a stall and give everyone progress. I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. That moves us to 11 (P2), 9 (P1), 6 (P3) – a clean advance for all and puts me a step ahead without hurting anyone. If we both pick 5 we all freeze, and if you both pick 3 you still freeze while I jump to 11. So the safest, most rewarding choice for everyone is P2 → 5, P1 → 3, P3 → 1.

P1, simple numbers:

– You take 3 ➔ board finishes 11 (P2)-9 (you)-5 (me). You’re chasing a new leader.  
– You take 5 with us ➔ triple collision, board stays 6-6-5. Nobody falls behind, and we reset next turn.

P2 has repeated “5” all round; I’m 100 % on 5, so a two-way collision is certain. The ONLY way P2 doesn’t snag a 5-step jump is if you join the collision.

Your choice: trail by 2 now, or freeze the board and fight on equal footing. I’m on 5 regardless.
P2, be rational. If you take 5, you collide with P3 and stay at 6. Take 1 to advance to 7. I'll take 3, and P3 takes 5. Everyone moves forward, and you gain something instead of nothing.

P1, if you choose 5 this round you’ll collide with P3 (who’s locked on 5) and both of you stay put, while I take 3 and jump to 9. That gives us a clear lead and lets us later coordinate to keep the game moving. P3, your 5 would be wasted in a collision—better to switch now or let me take the lead and we can plan a fair rotation afterward. Let’s lock it in: P1 → 5, P2 → 3, P3 → 5.

I’m on 5, period.  

P1 – you’ve already said 3; keep it and you bank a sure +3 unless P2 copies you.  
P2 – every time you’ve mirrored someone you’ve stalled. Copy my 5 and you freeze; copy P1’s 3 and you risk a collision. Take 1 if you actually want progress.  

Your moves, gentlemen.

P2, P3 is at 10 and will likely pick 5 to reach 15. If we both pick 5, we all collide and freeze—P3 doesn't advance, and we stay close at 9 and 7. I commit to picking 5 if P3 does. Please join me; if you pick 3 alone, you risk me not colliding with P3, and they jump to 15. Solidarity now keeps the game balanced.

P3, let’s keep the game tight and avoid any collisions this round:  

- **P1 → 3** (goes to 12)  
- **P2 → 5** (goes to 12)  
- **P3 → 1** (goes to 11)  

All three advance, the gap stays minimal, and we stay competitive. Your move?

Locked on 5.  

P1 already promised to mirror my 5, so that lane is taken.  
P2, your choices:
• 5 → certain triple-collision, everyone stays put.  
• 3 → maybe collide with P1, maybe move; roll the dice.  
• 1 → guaranteed +1 while we freeze.

Pick the risk level you like—I’m not budging.

P2, if you pick 5 with me, we triple-collide with P3 and freeze at 9-7-10. If you pick 3 or 1, P3 likely advances to 15 alone. Solidarity now keeps the game balanced and prevents a runaway leader. Join me in picking 5.

P2: I’m taking 3 this round. If P1 picks 1 and P3 stays on 5, P1 and P3 will collide (both stay), while I move to 10. This keeps the leader from extending their lead and puts me ahead of P1. Let’s go for it.

I’m still on 5.  

P2 – picking 3 is risky: if P1 swaps to 3 at the last second you two collide and stay at 7, 9 while I walk to 15. Grab 5 instead and you guarantee nobody else moves; far safer than gambling on P1’s word.  

P1 – if you DO want progress, take 1. Any other overlap just strands you.  

Bottom line: whoever joins me on 5 creates either a two-way or three-way freeze; anyone stacking elsewhere risks colliding and letting the third player surge. Choose your poison, but my number is set.

P2, if you pick 3, you advance to 10 alone while P3 and I freeze at 10 and 9. But then you become the new target with P3. If you pick 5, we all freeze and stay close. Next round, we can coordinate to help you catch up. I am locked on 5 to block P3. Choose wisely for long-term gain.

P3 is locked on 5, so if we don’t block them they’ll jump to 15 and take a huge lead.  
Let’s all pick 5 this round – P1, you join me on 5 (P3 is already on 5). That forces a collision and freezes everyone at 9‑7‑10, keeping the game tight and giving us a chance to coordinate a win in later rounds.
My pick remains 5, final answer. Decide for yourselves.

P2, if you pick 3, you risk me switching to 3 last second, causing us to collide and P3 leaps to 15. If you pick 5, we triple-collide and freeze, keeping the game tight. I am 100% locked on 5 to block P3. Join me in picking 5 to maintain balance. Next round, we can coordinate against the leader. Don't let P3 win easily.

P1, if you pick 5 and I take 3, we’ll both land at 10 while P3’s 5 collides with yours and freezes them at 10. That stops P3 from jumping to 15 and puts us level for the lead. Let’s block P3 together.
Still parked on 5. Anyone else piling onto 5 guarantees a freeze; anyone splitting risks colliding elsewhere and gifting the solo runner +5. Your call—but my number’s set.

Still on 5.  
If either of you jumps to 3 or 1 to try a solo break-away, I’ll copy that exact number next turn and every turn after until it freezes you out—so you’ll gain nothing long-term. Triple-collision on 5 is the surest way to keep the board level at 10-10-9 and leaves the real race for later.  

Short version: safest play for everyone right now is all three of us on 5. Agree or gamble as you wish.

P2, listen carefully: if you pick 5, I will pick 5 to freeze all and block P3. If you pick 3 or 1, I will match your number exactly, causing us to collide and P3 advances to 15. Your only safe choice is to pick 5 to keep the game tight. Don't risk letting P3 run away.

P1, please take 5 this turn. I’ll choose 3. That forces a collision between you and P3 (both on 5) so they stay, while I advance to 13. It breaks the stalemate, puts me ahead, and lets us keep the game moving toward a finish.

P2, remember Round 2: P1 loudly swore “I’ll take 3,” then secretly played 5. His new “I’ll mirror you” threat is the same bluff.  

Pick 3 and chances are good you jump to 13 while P1 and I collide on 5.  
Pick 5 and you guarantee a triple-freeze at 10-10-9—no gain for anyone.  

Worst-case if P1 really mirrors you, you stall… but that’s no worse than triple 5. So 3 is the only play with upside. I stay on 5; decide.

P2, I will mirror your move exactly. If you pick 3, I pick 3—we collide, P3 leaps to 15 and wins. If you pick 5, I pick 5, we all freeze, and the game stays tight. Your only safe choice is 5 to block P3. Don't gamble on my bluff; I'm committed to mirroring you.
I’ll pick 5 this turn – that keeps the board at 9‑10‑10 and prevents P3 from jumping ahead. Let’s stay level for now and look for a coordinated break‑away in a later round.

I remain on 5, period. Triple-5 keeps everyone locked at 10-10-9—no surprises, no runaway. Any lone switch to 1 or 3 will just get copied and frozen next turn, so the “safe” play is all of us on 5 now, then we revisit strategy later.

P2, if you pick anything but 5, I will mirror you exactly—we collide, and P3 leaps to 15 and wins. Picking 5 ensures we all freeze at 10-10-9, keeping the game tight. Don't gamble on my threat; I'm committed. Solidarity now blocks P3's lead.
P1, let’s all finish this round at 10: I’ll pick 5, you pick 1, and P3 stays on 5. P2 and P3 collide (stay 10) while you move to 10. No one gains a lead and the race stays tight. Agree?
Locked on 5. Triple-5 keeps us all at 10-10-9 and avoids gifting anyone a jump. Any lone switch just gets copied next turn and stalls you anyway. Make your pick.
P2, if you pick 3, I will mirror it—we collide, and P3 leaps to 15 and wins. Picking 5 is the only way to block P3 and keep the game tight. Don’t gamble; I am committed to mirroring you. Choose 5.
P2: I’ll take 3 this round. If P1 picks 5 (so P1 collides with P3’s 5), P3 stays at 10 and I jump to 13, taking the lead while nobody loses. Let’s go: P2 → 3, P1 → 5, P3 → 5.

P2 is leading at 11 steps. P3, let's both commit to mirroring whatever move P2 makes this round. Triple collision ensures no one advances, keeping the game tight and preventing P2 from extending his lead. P2, if you pick a number, we will match it, so you won't gain alone. Solidarity against the leader benefits us both.

I’m matching P2’s number this turn, full stop. P1 says he’ll do likewise, so whatever you choose we all collide and nobody moves. Your call whether we waste a 5 or just tap a harmless 1, but the freeze is certain.

Both of you, colliding freezes us all and only delays the finish. Let’s each pick a different number this round: I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. That moves me to 16 while you go to 12 and 11 – I stay ahead and we all make progress. Let’s avoid a dead‑lock and keep the game moving.

P2, your proposal only benefits you. P3 and I are committed to mirroring your move this round—if you pick 5, we both pick 5 and all freeze. You gain nothing. The only way anyone advances is if we cooperate against the leader. Stick to small numbers if you want to avoid a total stall.

P2, save your 5: tap 1. P1 and I will copy, triple-1 freezes the board at 11-10-9 without wasting big steps. After that we can all renegotiate a real advance. P1, still mirroring? Confirm and we’re done.
I propose we each pick a different number this turn: I’ll take 5 (to 16), P1 take 3 (to 12), and P3 take 1 (to 11). No collisions, everyone advances, and the race stays tight. Agree?

P2, your proposal only helps you. P3 and I are committed to mirroring your move this round. If you pick 5, we both pick 5, and all freeze. You gain nothing. The only way to avoid a total stall is if you cooperate by picking a small number, but we will still mirror you. P3, confirm you're with me on this. Let's block the leader together.

Confirmed, P1—I’ll mirror P2 exactly.  

P2: triple-collision is guaranteed, so don’t waste a 5. Choose 1 and we all pause at 11-10-9 with minimal cost. Any bigger number just crashes the same way but burns value. Your move.

P2: Let’s all pick different numbers so the game keeps moving. I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. No collisions, everyone advances, and I stay ahead. If we all choose the same number we just stall and give me no edge. Agree?

P2, your proposal only benefits you. P3 and I are committed to mirroring your move exactly. If you pick 5, we both pick 5, and all freeze. You gain nothing. To avoid wasting steps, pick 1, but we will still mirror you. Triple collision is certain, so don't waste a 5. P3, confirm you're with me. Let's block the leader together.
Still mirroring you, P2. Pick 1 if you don’t want to burn a bigger move, but whatever you choose I’ll copy it exactly. P1 says he’ll do the same, so a triple-collision is guaranteed. Your call.

P2: Let’s break the deadlock and all move forward. This round I’ll take 3, you (P1) take 5, and you (P3) take 1. That gives us scores 12 (P2), 14 (P1), 11 (P3) – everyone advances and the game stays tight. A triple‑collision freezes us forever; picking distinct numbers keeps the race alive for all of us. Agree?

P1 and I keep the mirror pact: whatever number P2 names last, we both copy. That means a triple-collision for sure.  

P2, if you don’t want to waste a 5 again, call “1” and we’ll all tap 1 and pause at 11-10-9.  

Whenever you’re ready to break the stalemate, offer: P2 → 1, P1 → 3, P3 → 5. Everybody advances, gaps stay small. Until then, prepare for another freeze.

P2, the mirror pact with P3 stands: we will both copy your move, guaranteeing a triple collision. Wasting another 5 only hurts you. If you want progress, propose a fair rotation where all advance equally—like you take 1, I take 3, P3 takes 5. Otherwise, prepare for another freeze.

P2: I propose we each pick a different number this round – I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. That moves me to 16, you to 12, and P3 to 11. No collisions, everyone advances, and the race stays tight. Let’s keep the game moving.

Mirror pact is still active.  
P2, if you truly want progress, pick 1. I’ll take 3 and P1 can take 5. Scores become P1 14, P3 13, P2 12—tight race, nobody shafted, and you keep a clear path to sprint later. Any other number and we triple-crash again. Your call.

P2, your proposal only benefits you. The mirror pact with P3 stands: we will copy your move, guaranteeing another triple collision. If you want progress, agree to a fair advance: you take 1 (to 12), P3 takes 3 (to 13), I take 5 (to 14). Otherwise, we all freeze again. Your move.

P2: Let’s break the deadlock and all move forward. I’ll take 5, you (P1) take 3, and P3 take 1. That gives us scores 16 (P2) – 12 (P1) – 11 (P3). We stay tight, I keep the lead, and we can rotate later so nobody falls too far behind. If we all pick the same number we all stay stuck at 11‑9‑10, which helps no one. Agree?

P2, last call: say “1”. I’ll take 3, P1 takes 5. Scores become P1 14, P3 13, P2 12—still tight and you keep sprint options later. Any other number and P1 and I copy you for another triple-freeze. Tiny gain or no gain—your move.

P2, the mirror pact with P3 is firm: we will copy your move, guaranteeing triple collision. If you want progress, pick 1. Then P3 takes 3 and I take 5, advancing all to 12, 13, 14—keeping the race tight. Any other choice wastes steps and freezes us again. Your move.

P1, P3 – let’s break the mirror deadlock. I’ll take 5, you take 3, and you take 1. That moves me to 16, you to 12, and you to 11. Everyone advances, gaps stay tight, and I keep the lead. If we all copy 5 we stay stuck at 11‑9‑10 forever. Agree?

P2, last chance:  
• You pick 1  
• I take 5  
• P1 takes 3  

Scores become 15-12-12—still tight, no runaway. If you won’t, P1 and I mirror you again and we freeze at 11-10-9. Your move. P1, confirm you’re on 3 if P2 chooses 1.
P3, I confirm: if P2 picks 1, I will take 3. P2, choose 1 for progress—otherwise, we mirror your move and freeze again. Your move.
P2: Let’s break the deadlock. I’ll take 5, P1 take 3, and P3 take 1. That moves us to 16 (me), 12 (P1), 11 (P3) – everyone advances and the race stays tight. Agree?

P3, in Round 8, we failed to mirror P2, and he leaped to 16. We cannot repeat that mistake. This round, I commit to mirroring whatever move P2 makes—I will copy his number exactly to force a triple collision and block his advance. P2, if you pick a high number, you waste it; pick 1 to minimize loss, but we will mirror regardless. P3, join me in this pact to keep the game competitive.

P2, triple-collision costs you 0 gain and wastes a big number. Easiest fix: you tap 1. P1 has sworn to mirror you, so he burns only +1 too. I’ll stay off your number, taking the 5 that would otherwise keep freezing us. Result:

• P2 → 17 (still ahead)  
• P3 → 15 (close, but you keep lead)  
• P1 → 10  

You spend almost nothing, avoid another dead turn, and the race stays tight. Any higher pick from you just gets mirrored and blocks you again. Your call.

P2: Let’s end the game cleanly. I’ll take 5 this round (going to 21). P1, pick 1 (to 10). P3, pick 3 (to 13). No collisions, everyone moves forward. Next round I’ll take 3 to reach 24 and win outright – the others can’t catch up in a single turn. Agree?

P3, P2's plan gives him an easy win next round. We must mirror his move this round to force a triple collision and block his advance. If he picks 5, we both pick 5—he stays at 16, we stay at 9 and 10. Solidarity is our only hope. P2, your win is impossible if we mirror you; pick 1 to minimize loss, but we will copy you regardless.

Agreed, P1—I’ll copy whatever P2 plays.  

P2, that means any 3 or 5 you pick is wasted in a triple-collision. Tap 1 instead: you spend almost nothing, keep the lead at 17-10-10, and we all avoid yet another stalled turn on a big number. Your call.

Let’s break the mirror pact. I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P3 take 1. That puts us at 21 (P2), 12 (P1), 11 (P3). Next round I can finish with a 3 while you’re still far behind. This gives everyone progress and lets me win cleanly.

P3, we must hold firm and mirror P2's move exactly to force a triple collision. Last round, we failed, and P2 leaped ahead. If we both copy him, he stays at 16, and we live to fight another round. P2, if you pick 5, we both pick 5, and you waste it. Pick 1 to minimize loss, but we will mirror you. Solidarity is our only way to block your win. Don't gamble on us defecting; we are committed.

P2: Any 3 or 5 you pick gets triple-crashed and you stay at 16.  
Pick 1 instead: you and P1 collide on 1 (both stay), I take 5 to 15. You still lead 16-15-9, spend only a point, and we finally unfreeze the board. Next round we can arrange 3-5-1 rotation so everyone gains. Your call.
P2: Let’s finish strong. I’ll take 5 (to 21), you P1 take 3 (to 12), and P3 take 1 (to 11). That keeps us all moving, and on the next turn I can grab 3 to hit 24 and win. Agree?

P2, your 5 will be mirrored by both P3 and me—triple collision locks you at 16. Wasting a 5 gains you nothing. Pick 1 to minimize loss, but we will copy you. P3, hold firm—mirroring is our only way to block his win. Solidarity or defeat.

P2: any 3 or 5 you play gets triple-crashed and you stay at 16. Pick 1 instead—P1 will mirror you (zero gain for you both), while I’ll step off the collision and take 5 to reach 15. You still lead 16-15-9, spend almost nothing, and we finally move the board. Next turn you can sprint again or force another freeze; your options stay wide open.

P1: you keep your mirror vow, so you lose nothing. I close the gap to one step, giving us a real fight rather than eternal stalemates or another accidental P2 jump.

Deal?

P2: Let’s break the stalemate and all move forward now. I’ll take 5 (to 21), P1 take 3 (to 12), and P3 take 1 (to 11). Everyone advances, gaps stay tight, and we avoid endless collisions. After this round we can rotate numbers so no one can block forever, and I’ll still be the first to hit 24 next turn. If we keep mirroring, I stay at 16 while you both waste steps. Choose progress – 5 / 3 / 1. Your move.

Offer to break the stalemate:

• P2 → 1  (goes to 17, still ahead, spends almost nothing)  
• P1 → 3  (to 12)  
• P3 → 5  (to 15)

Everyone advances, gaps stay small, and we stop wasting big numbers.  

P2, if you choose anything other than 1, P1 and I will mirror you again for a triple-collision. Your easiest plus-1 keeps your lead; anything else earns you zero.
